questions.text: A middle-aged man complains of upper abdominal pain after a heavy meal. There is Tenderness in the upper abdomen and on x-ray, widening of the mediastinum is seen with pneumo-mediastinum. What is the diagnosis?
questions.correct_answer: A. Spontaneous perforation of the esophagus
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Spontaneous perforation of the esophagus They are also known as Boerhaave’s syndrome. Keywords: On X-ray – pump-mediastinum; after a heavy meal Boerhaave's syndrome is characterized by a transmural tear of the distal esophagus induced by a sudden increase in pressure. Boerhaave syndrome classically presents as the Mackler triad of chest pain, vomiting, and subcutaneous emphysema due to esophageal rupture. Ideal management for Boerhaave syndrome involves a combination of both conservative and surgical interventions. The mainstays of therapy include the following: Intravenous volume resuscitation Administration of broad-spectrum antibiotics Prompt endoscopic and surgical intervention

Highyeild:

Boerhaave Syndrome Spontaneous rupture usually occurs on the left posterolateral side of the distal esophagus, into the left pleural cavit y or just above the gastroesophageal junction. Typically, male patients (85%) aged between 40 to 60 years with a recent history of vomiting are affected. Clinical Features Spontaneous esophageal perforation is characterized by Mackler's triad of thoracic pain, vomiting, and cervical subcutaneous emphysema. Thoracic perforations cause substernal and epigastric pain. While mediastinal emphysema and pleural effusions are common, early cervical subcutaneous emphysema is observed in only 20% or less of patients. Increasing contamination and inflammation of the mediastinum and pleural cavities lead to fever and sepsis . Patients with an abdominal perforation experience epigastric abdominal pain, which is also frequently referred to the back and left shoulder

Extraedge:

The diagnosis of hydropneumothorax can be confirmed by performing a contrast esophagogram , which has a high success rate of detecting extravasation in 90% of patients. To avoid the risk of barium extravasation into the pleura or mediastinum, gastrografin (a water-soluble contrast agent) is preferred over barium. If the initial esophagogram is negative, a barium study may follow. Chest CT can also aid in diagnosis by revealing mediastinal air and fluid at the site of perforation. Endoscopy may be necessary if the esophagogram is negative or if surgery is planned. Treatment involves immediate resuscitation, securing the airway, administering intravenous fluids, and starting broad-spectrum antibiotics.

Table:

Primary surgical repair is generally recommended Debridement of devitalized tissue + Esophageal diversion or resection + Creation of an esophagostomy + Wide drainage + feeding jejunostomy mortality rate 8-20% mortality rate>50%

questions.text: A male patient presented with persistent abdominal pain that is less responsive to medical treatment, along with melena, vomiting and peritoneal irritation. On investigations it is found that fasting hypergastrinemia is present and basal acid output (BAO) is greater than 10 mEq/h. The diagnosis is made of gastrinoma. Which is the most common site of gastrinoma in MEN - 1 syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Duodenum Wall of the first part of duodenum is the most common site of gastrinoma. A gastrinoma is a gastrin-secreting tumor that can occur in the pancreas. More than 70% of the gastrinomas in MEN 1 syndrome and most sporadic gastrinomas are located in the first and second part of the duodenum. More than 80% of gastrinomas arise within the “triangle of gastrinoma” defined as the confluence of: The cystic and common bile duct superiorly The second and third portions of the duodenum inferiorly And the neck and body of the pancreas medially. The triad of : Non beta islet cell tumors of the pancreas (gastrinomas), hypergastrinemia, and severe ulcer disease is known as Zollinger-Ellison syndrome (ZES). Most sensitive test for the diagnosis of ZES is Fasting serum gastrin measurement. What is multiple endocrine neoplasia (MEN) type 1? Multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1 (MEN1) also known as Wermer syndrome is an endocrine tumor syndrome caused by inactivating mutations of the MEN1 tumor suppressor gene at the 11q13 locus. MEN1 predisposes to the development of tumors in target neuroendocrine tissues. Type 2 MEN (MEN2), in contrast, is caused by mutations in the RET proto-oncogene and typically presents as medullary thyroid carcinoma, hyperparathyroidism, or pheochromocytoma. The most common tumors seen in MEN1 involve the : parathyroid gland, islet cells of the pancreas, and pituitary gland. Other endocrine tumors seen in MEN1 include adrenal cortical tumors, neuroendocrine tumors (previously called carcinoid tumors), and rare pheochromocytoma, as well as tumors in other parts of the digestive tract.

Highyeild:

Gastrinoma is a non-beta islet cell tumor of the pancreas that produces excessive amounts of gastrin , leading to a condition called Zollinger-Ellison syndrome (ZES). ZES is characterized by fulminating ulcer diathesis in the stomach, duodenum, or atypical sites , recurrent ulceration despite "adequate" therapy, and non-beta islet cell tumors of the pancreas (gastrinoma). Gastrinoma is a rare disease, affecting between 5 and 4 in a million. Approximately 0.1% of patients with duodenal ulcers have evidence of ZES. In sporadic disease , the tumors are mostly located in the duodenum (60-80%) and are small (<5mm) and multiple . In MEN 1 , all tumors are in the The vast majority (approximately 90%) occur within the "gastrinoma triangle." Diagnosis of ZES is based on an elevated fasting serum gastrin ( FSG ). If the FSG is more than 10-fold elevated, the diagnosis is confirmed. If the FSG is less than 10-fold higher, a secretin provocation test should be performed.

Extraedge:

Localisation studies are then indicated as the tumors are often small and multiple. The majority of gastrinomas have a high density of somatotropin receptors. 68Ga-labelled SSAs with PET-CT have been found to be sensitive and specific. If not available, somatostatin scintigraphy (SRS) and EUS should be done. Chromogranin A is an unreliable test for gastrinoma. Treatment of gastrinoma involves surgery, which should be performed by an experienced surgeon. All patients with sporadic gastrinoma without metastases should have a surgical operation. In MEN 1/gastrinoma , surgery is not recommended for patients with tumors <2cm . Tumors >2cm are enucleated. Parathyroidectomy reduces gastric acid secretion.

questions.text: An elderly man presents to you with a long standing mole over his face which is now Increasing in size and showing irregular borders what is your diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Superficial spreading melanoma In the above given case, it is long standing and increasing in size which shows irregular borders probable a superficial spreading melanoma Superficial spreading melanoma (SSM): This is the most common presentation (70%), usually arising in a pre-existing nevus after several years of slow change, followed by rapid growth in the preceding months before presentation.

Highyeild:

Malignant Melanoma : Melanoma is a cancer of melanocytes and can, therefore, arise in skin, mucosa, retina and the leptomeninges. Epidemiology : Exposure to UVR Common among young adults Rising Incidence Macroscopic Features : Change in size Shape Colour Thickness (elevation/nodularity or ulceration) Satellite lesions (pigment spreading into surrounding area) Tingling/itching/serosanguineous discharge (usually late signs) Four variants : Superficial Spreading Melanoma Nodular Melanoma Lentigo Melanoma Acral Lentiginous Melanoma Miscellaneous : Amelanotic Melanoma Desmoplastic Melanoma Staging : Summary of the American Joint Committee on Cancer melanoma staging, 8th edition. Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: D. Nodular melanoma (NM) tends to be more aggressive than SSM, with a shorter clinical onset. They typically appear as blue/black papules,1–2 cm in diameter, and because they lack the horizontal growth phase, they tend to be sharply demarcated. Option: B . Lentigo maligna melanoma (LMM) was previously also known as Hutchinson’s melanotic freckle. It presents as a slow-growing, variegated brown macule on the face, neck or hands of the elderly. Option: C . Acral lentiginous melanoma (ALM) ALM affects the soles of feet and palms of hands. It usually presents as a flat, irregular macule in later life. 25% are amelanotic and may mimic a fungal infection or pyogenic granuloma.

Extraedge:

Malignant melanoma is the most common primary malignant tumour of the eye and originates in the pigmented cells of the choroid ,ciliary body or iris. Malignant melanoma of the anus is very rare and usually presents as a bluish-black soft mass that may mimic a thrombosed external pile, although it may be amelanotic Malignant Melanoma Penis is an uncommon tumour with the principles of management being the same as for squamous cell carcinoma. Bloodborne metastatic disease is, however, more common.

questions.text: Management of a Renal Cell Cancer less than 4 cm in size?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Partial nephrectomy Radical Nephrectomy is indicated for tumors less than 4cms while partial nephrectomy is indicated for tumors between 4 and 7 cm. Hence Partial Nephrectomy is appropriate.

Highyeild:

Classically, radical nephrectomy involved the removal of the entire kidney enclosed in Gerota’s fascia with the ipsilateral adrenal gland and regional lymphadenectomy. Most are now performed laparoscopically, and the adrenal is spared if there is no involvement on CT/MRI. Lymphadenectomy is indicated only in high-risk patients with large primary tumours and enlarged lymph nodes. Radical nephrectomy remains the standard gold treatment for localised disease. Incidental detection of small renal masses (tumours <4 cm)nephron-sparing surgery is being performed. Partial nephrectomy should be the treatment of choice in tumours less than 4 cm, in well-selected tumours between 4 and 7 cm, in bilateral tumours, in tumours in solitary kidneys and patients with pre-existing renal dysfunction. Because of the limitation of ischaemia time, minimally invasive techniques should be reserved for tumours with non-complex anatomy, as predicted by nephelometry scores. Alternative techniques such as surveillance, cryoablation or radiofrequency ablation of small renal tumours may be offered in patients with high surgical risk (e.g. elderly patients and patients with multiple comorbidities). Active surveillance is based on the fact that most incidental tumours detected in the elderly grow slowly and have a low chance of local invasion or metastasis. Classically, radical nephrectomy involved the removal of the entire kidney enclosed in Gerota’s fascia with the ipsilateral adrenal gland and regional lymphadenectomy. Most are now performed laparoscopically, and the adrenal is spared if there is no involvement on CT/MRI.

Extraedge:

Following unilateral nephrectomy, there is considerable compensation by the remaining kidney and donors are usually left with 70% of their donation GFR. The mortality from donor nephrectomy is approximately 1:3000, and significant morbidity occurs in <5%

questions.text: A chronic smoker presents with pain, & cramping in the leg muscles during walking and climbing stairs. The patient typically has pain after walking nearly 200 meters. The pain disappears with rest. True statement about the given condition is?

options.label: B
options.text: Most common site is the calf

options.label: C
options.text: Claudication distance can vary from day to day

options.label: D
options.text: Relieved after getting out of bed and walking

questions.correct_answer: B. Most common site is the calf
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Most common site is the calf Intermittent claudication, also known as vascular claudication, is a symptom that describes muscle pain on mild exertion. Most common in the calf muscle It is classically associated with peripheral artery disease, and can progress to critical limb ischemia if left untreated.

Highyeild:

Claudication: Intermittent claudication occurs as a result of anaerobic muscle metabolism and is classically described as debilitating cramp-like pain felt in the muscles that are: brought on by walking; not present on taking the first step (unlike osteoarthritis); relieved by rest in both the standing and sitting positions, usually within 5 minutes (unlike nerve compression from lumbar intervertebral disc prolapse or osteoarthritis of the spine or spinal stenosis, which are typically relieved only when resting in the sitting position for longer than 5 minutes). The distance that a patient is able to walk without stopping varies (claudication distance) only slightly from day to day. It is decreased, first, by increasing the work demands and hence oxygen requirements of the muscles affected, e.g. walking uphill, increasing the speed of walking and/or carrying heavy weights, and, second, by general health conditions that reduce the oxygen delivery capacity of the arterial system, e.g. anemia or cardiorespiratory disease. The muscle group affected by claudication is classically one anatomical level below the level of arterial disease and is usually felt in the posterior calf as the superficial femoral artery is the most commonly affected artery (70% of cases). Aortoiliac disease (30% of cases) may cause thigh or buttock claudication Leriche’s syndrome is buttock claudication combined with sexual impotence, which is secondary to arterial insufficiency

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A, C & D : Most common in the calf muscle, which occurs during exercise(not at rest)such as walking, and is relieved by a short period of rest

Extraedge:

Only one-quarter of patients presenting with intermittent claudication will experience symptomatic deterioration during their lifetime and the overall risk of progression to CLTI and amputation is small, with <5% of patients requiring amputation over a 5-year period.

questions.text: A Patient presents with halitosis and a swelling in the lateral aspect of the neck, which on pressing gives rise to a regurgitant air sound. Barium image is shown. Diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Pharyngeal pouch (Zenker’s diverticulum) Key words : on pressing there is regurgitant air. Zenker diverticulum is a pulsion diverticulum of the hypopharynx, usually seen in elderly people. Zenker diverticula are lined with stratified squamous epithelium with a thin lamina propria. No muscular layer exists. The pathologic process in Zenker diverticulum involves herniation of the esophageal mucosa posteriorly between the cricopharyngeus (CP) muscle and the inferior pharyngeal constrictor muscles. Therefore a Zenker diverticulum is a false diverticulum. The retention of food elements and secretions within the lesion’s pouch frequently leads to halitosis, regurgitation, aspiration, and dysphagia in patient. Aspiration & pneumonitis are the most common complications. Following modalities of treatment can be used : Open surgery: Diverticulectomy / Diverticulopexy Endoscopic Diverticulectomy (Dohlman procedure) Laser technique <2cm Cricopharyngeal Myotomy (CPM) only 2 to 5 cm 5cm CPM with Diverticulectomy

questions.text: A patient presents with progressive dysphagia involving both fluids and solids, Regurgitation, Chest pain, heartburn & weight loss image of Barium study is shown, what is your diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Achalasia cardia Achalasia is a primary esophageal motility disorder characterized by the absence of esophageal peristalsis and impaired relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES) in response to swallowing. These abnormalities cause a functional obstruction at the gastroesophageal junction (GEJ) leading to above described signs and symptoms. Specific tests for achalasia are barium swallow and esophageal manometry. The barium swallow shows classical Bird beak appearance. Treatment options include: Sublingual nifedipine / nitrates Pneumatic dilation Botox injection Surgical myomectomy Diffuse esophageal spasm Carcinoma esophagus

Highyeild:

Achalasia Cardia It is the most common hypomotility disorder of the esophagus . Achalasia refers to the failure of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES) to relax . Both the muscle of the esophagus and LES are affected. The prevailing theory suggests that destruction of the nerves to LES is the primary pathology, and degeneration of neuromuscular function of the body of the esophagus is secondary. It is a premalignant condition that may lead to squamous cell carcinoma. Achalasia can be seen in Triple A syndrome or Allgrove disease , which involves Achalasia, Alacrima, and ACTH-resistant Adrenal insufficiency . It is caused by progressive inflammation and selective loss of inhibitory myenteric neurons in Auerbach’s plexus of the esophagus that normally secrete VIP and nitric oxide . This results in the failure of relaxation of LES and aperistalsis of the esophageal body, leading to functional obstruction at the level of the GE junction and gradual dilatation of the esophagus. The classic triad of symptoms includes dysphagia , regurgitation , and weight loss . Other symptoms commonly seen are heartburn, postprandial choking, and nocturnal coughing.

Table:

#MANTRA Treatment options for Achalasia Cardia : Early stage : Sublingual nitroglycerin, nitrates, or calcium channel blockers can provide temporary relief of chest pressure before or after a meal. Bougie dilation up to 54 French may offer several months of relief but requires repeated dilations to be sustainable. Botulinum toxin injection directly into the LES can relax the LES and provide symptomatic relief for years, but symptoms may recur more than 50% of the time within 6 months. Laparoscopic Heller myotomy is the preferred surgical option , where the extent of myotomy is 2 cm above GE junction to 1 cm below, over the stomach. Partial antireflux procedure (Toupet or Dor fundoplication) can be performed to restore a barrier to reflux and decrease postoperative symptoms. Esophagectomy may be considered for megaesophagus, sigmoid esophagus, failure of more than one myotomy, or an undilatable reflux stricture .

questions.text: A 20 year old boy is brought to the emergency bay following a RTA with respiratory distress and hypotension. He has subcutaneous emphysema physical examination shows no air entry on the right side. What is the next best step in the management?

options.label: A
options.text: Start IV fluids after insertion of wide bore IV line

options.label: B
options.text: Needle decompression in the 5th intercostal space

questions.correct_answer: B. Needle decompression in the 5th intercostal space
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Needle decompression in the 5th intercostal space Key words : no air entry on one side following an RTA. The above clinical scenario is suggestive of tension pneumothorax. Treatment is immediate needle decompression by inserting a large-bore (eg, 14- or 16-gauge) needle into the 5th intercostal space in the midclavicular line. This releases the pressure and air entry reestablishes. Because needle decompression causes a simple pneumothorax, tube thoracostomy should be done immediately thereafter. A large right pneumothorax with marked shift of the mediastinum to the left.

Highyeild:

Tension pneumothorax is a medical emergency that can result in respiratory failure or cardiovascular collapse. It can be diagnosed clinically without the need for radiographic confirmation. The symptoms of tension pneumothorax include deviation of the trachea , unilaterally absent or diminished breath sounds, and cardiopulmonary compromise. If these symptoms are present, thoracic decompression should be rapidly performed with a large-bore needle or tube thoracostomy, depending on the availability of equipment and supplies.

Extraedge:

In addition to tension pneumothorax, massive hemothorax also requires tube thoracostomy with evacuation of blood and reexpansion of the lung. Severe pulmonary contusion may require aggressive mechanical ventilation with elevated levels of positive end-expiratory pressure. However, to avoid loss of positive end-expiratory pressure, the ventilator should not be repeatedly disconnected for suction or manual ventilation as oxygenation will only improve with an uninterrupted circuit

questions.text: A Patient presents with peritonitis and during surgery a diverticular perforation is seen with fecal peritonitis. What is the Hinchey’s stage?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

STAGE 4 Hinchey Classification is used to describe perforations of the colon due to diverticulitis. The Hinchey classification: Hinchey I - localised abscess (para-colonic) Hinchey II - pelvic abscess Hinchey III - purulent peritonitis (the presence of pus in the abdominal cavity) Hinchey IV - feculent peritonitis. (Intestinal perforation allowing feces into abdominal cavity)

Highyeild:

Diverticula are abnormal hollow outpouchings in the gastrointestinal tract. They can be classified as congenital or acquired depending on the presence of the muscularis layer in the diverticulum. The majority of patients with diverticulosis do not experience symptoms, but 10-30% may develop complications. Complications of diverticular disease include diverticulitis, abscess, peritonitis, intestinal obstruction, hemorrhage, and fistula formation. The degree of infection significantly impacts the outcome of acute diverticulitis, with patients with inflammatory masses having lower mortality than those with perforation. Classifications, such as the Hinchey classification , have been developed to better understand complicated diverticulitis.

questions.text: A patient present with clinical evidence of elevated serum calcium levels with non specific symptoms as fatigue, pain and weakness as well as polydipsia, polyuria, and nephrolithiasis. Gastrointestinal symptoms include constipation, anorexia, nausea, and vomiting. The patient is diagnosed with parathyroid adenoma, how do we confirm the removal of the correct gland after surgery?

options.label: A
options.text: 50% reduction in PTH within 10 mins of gland removal

options.label: B
options.text: 50% reduction in PTH within 5 mins of gland removal

options.label: C
options.text: 25% reduction in PTH within 10 mins of gland removal

options.label: D
options.text: 25% reduction in PTH within 5 mins of gland removal

questions.correct_answer: A. 50% reduction in PTH within 10 mins of gland removal
questions.explanation:
Solution:

50% reduction in PTH within 10 mins of gland removal To confirm the removal of the correct gland after surgery we use Miami riteria. The Miami criterion is a protocol that uses a “> 50% parathormone (PTH) drop” from either the greatest pre-incision or pre-excision measurement of PTH in a blood sample taken 10 min following resection of hyperfunctioning glands. A parathyroid adenoma is a benign tumor of the parathyroid gland. It generally causes hyperparathyroidism. Parathyroid adenoma can be associated with overexpression of the cyclin D1 gene.

Highyeild:

After the removal of a parathyroid adenoma, the level of parathyroid hormone ( PTH ) should decrease rapidly, indicating the successful removal of the overactive gland. The Miami criteria were developed to determine the extent of resection in parathyroidectomy. A drop in the parathyroid hormone ( PTH ) level into the normal range and to less than 50% preoperative PTH at 10 minutes is considered a reliable predictor of single-gland disease. Intraoperative PTH measurements can guide the conversion from a focused to a cervical exploration if no such drop is observed, indicating the possibility of multigland disease. Routine use of intraoperative PTH measurements is controversial due to high false-positive and false-negative rates. The half-life of circulating PTH is 3-5 minutes, and a significant drop should be detected in plasma PTH following the resection of a single adenoma.

Table:

#MANTRA Localisation paradigm and management strategies. 4D CT, four-dimensional computed tomography; MIBI, 2-methoxy-2- methylpropylisonitrile; MIP, minimally invasive parathyroidectomy; US, ultrasonography

questions.text: A patient presents with dysphagia esophageal manometry was performed – it revealed abnormal spastic contractions in esophagus, >450 mm Hg pressure in the body. What is your diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Type 3 achalasia Achalasia is a heterogeneous disease categorized into 3 distinct types based on manometric patterns: Type I (classic) with minimal contractility in the esophageal body Type II with intermittent periods of PAN esophageal pressurization Type III (spastic) with premature or spastic distal esophageal contractions High-resolution manometry showing the 3 subtypes of achalasia: Treatment algorithm for patients with achalasia: EGD - esophagogastroduodenoscopy; HM - Heller myotomy; HRM - high-resolution manometry; PD - pneumatic dilation; POEM - peroral endoscopic myotomy .

Highyeild:

Achalasia is characterized by the failure of the lower esophageal sphincter (LOS) to relax and absent peristalsis, leading to incomplete emptying of the esophagus. The exact cause of achalasia is unknown but is postulated to be due to the loss of inhibitory ganglion cells in the myenteric plexus. Symptoms of achalasia include dysphagia, regurgitation, heartburn, and chest pain/odynophagia. Diagnosis of achalasia can be challenging as symptoms can be mild and easily misdiagnosed as gastroesophageal reflux disease (GORD). There are three types of achalasia: Type I (classic) shows absent peristalsis and incomplete relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES). Type II (variant) shows absent peristalsis, but with a pan-esophageal pressurization in response to swallowing. Type III (spastic) shows preserved peristalsis with elevated resting LES pressure. Hierarchy diagnostic algorithm of oesophageal motility disorders according to the Chicago classification 4.0. The broad categories of 'disorders of oesophagogastric junction (OGJ) outflow' and 'disorders of oesophageal peristalsis' are differentiated by the integrated relax- ation pressure (IRP). FLIP, functional lumen imaging planimetry; IBP, intrabolus pressurisation; LOS, lower oesophageal sphincter; MRS, multiple rapid swallow; OGJOO, oesophagogastric outflow obstruction; POP, pan-oesophageal pressurisation; RDC, rapid drink challenge; TBO, timed barium oesophagram.

questions.text: A patient presented with a lump in the breast, she was diagnosed with a Stage – II breast cancer, for with she underwent mastectomy. For breast reconstruction which of the following is the best flap.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

C. DIEP flap – deep inferior epigastric artery perforator flap Autologous tissue reconstruction is a way to rebuild the shape of breast after surgical removal of the cancer. There are different types of tissue flap surgery, named for the area of the body where the tissue is taken: TRAM (transverse rectus abdominis muscle) flap (image - a) Latissimus dorsi (LD) flap (image - b) DIEP (deep inferior epigastric artery perforator) flap (image - c) SIEA (superficial inferior epigastric artery) flap Gluteal free flap (image - d) TUG (transverse upper gracilis) flap The preferred donor site for Autologous breast reconstruction is the abdominal wall. Advantage of DIEP Flap: 1. The skin and subcutaneous fatty tissues of the lower abdomen provide tissue that has a soft texture that is perfect for breast reconstruction and Donor site morbidity is minimal. In function of these advantages the DIEP flap has become the “gold standard” for breast reconstruction in many hospitals.

Highyeild:

Breast reconstruction: Immediate breast reconstruction provides women with a breast mound right after surgery. Some women prefer delayed reconstruction after completing their adjuvant treatment. Silicone gel breast implants and autologous tissue can be used for immediate reconstruction. Silicone gel implants can be placed either prepectoral or subpectoral. Autologous tissue reconstructions can be done using flaps such as the latissimus dorsi, TRAM, anterolateral thigh, or DIEP free tissue transfers. The treatment algorithm commonly used for breast reconstruction includes the latissimus dorsi, TRAM, and DIEP flaps. In the UK, the DIEP flap is commonly used, but it requires microvascular surgical skills and an operative time of about four hours.

Extraedge:

Radiotherapy after inserting a silicone prosthesis often results in capsular contracture and unacceptable results. Achieving symmetry after breast reconstruction or BCS may require a cosmetic procedure such as mammoplasty or mastopexy. Patients may require more than one procedure to achieve symmetrisation.

questions.text: A baby is born with bowel herniating as shown in the image below, mother’s age is 19 years and has a history of smoking and alcohol consumption. What is your diagnosis?
questions.explanation:

Gastroschisis From the clinical condition and the image given above, stating that the mothers age at the time of delivery is 19 years with H/O of smoking and alcohol consumption, the most probable diagnosis would be Gastroschisis

Highyeild:

Gastroschisis is now the commonest anomaly in babies born to mothers under 20 years of age. The gastroschisis defect is usually just to the right of the umbilical cord , at the site of the obliterated right umbilical vein. Th e fascial defect is typically approximately 4 cm in diameter. Associated anomalies are not usually seen with gastroschisis except for a 10% rate of intestinal atresia Complications may include feeding problems, prematurity, intestinal atresia, and intrauterine growth retardation. Risk factors include the mother being young, and use of alcohol or tobacco Neonatal abdominal wall defects Gastroschisis Environmental risk factors (young maternal age, drug use) Bowel complications common (atresia, matting, volvulus) Associated anomalies rare Exomphalos Frequent association with aneuploidies and other genetic syndromes (e.g. Beckwith-Wiedemann) Other structural anomalies common (e.g. cardiac malformations) Large defects may contain liver (exomphalos major) and require delayed or staged closure

Its defect is generally more than 4 cm in diameter with an intact membranous sac, which is composed of an outer layer of amnion and an inner layer of peritoneum. Defects less than 4 cm in diameter are arbitrarily designated hernias of the cord. Infants with an omphalocele have an approximately 50% incidence of associated anomalies. Treatment involves surgery. This is typically done shortly after birth. Option D : Spigelian hernia is the type of ventral hernia where aponeurotic fascia pushes through a hole creating a bulge. questions.text: A man is brought to the emergency after he fell into a man hole and injured his perineum. He feels the urge to micturate but is unable to pass urine and there is blood at the tip of the meatus with extensive swelling of the penis and scrotum. What is the location of the injury?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Bulbar urethra In the given presentation there is blood at the tip of meatus with swelling of penis and scrotum which signifies the HEMATOMA of penis and scrotum. Therefore bulbar urethra has been injured in this patient.

Highyeild:

Bulbar urethral trauma The patient usually gives a history of a falling-astride injury, leading to blunt trauma of the perineum. Other common causes include falling from a tree, cycling, skating and industrial accidents. The bulbar urethra is crushed upwards onto the pubic bone, typically with significant bruising. Clinical features The signs of a ruptured bulbar urethra are perineal bruising and haematoma, typically with a butterfly distribution. There is usually bleeding from the urethral meatus and retention of urine. Management Investigations include a retrograde urethrogram (RGU). A gentle attempt at catheterisation may be made. If the catheter fails to drain urine, a suprapubic cystostomy is performed Delayed anastomotic urethroplasty is performed after 3 months with excellent success rates.

questions.text: A middle aged man presents with a swelling over the neck since childhood. Neck swelling has a bag of worm appearance. What is your diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Plexiform neurofibroma Plexiform neurofibromas represent an uncommon variant of neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF-1) in which neurofibromas arise from multiple nerves as bulging and deforming masses involving also connective tissue and skin folds hence the clinical description of lesions as “bags of worms.”

Highyeild:

There are two distinct neurofbromatosis (NF) syndromes, in which Schwann cells form tumours Each is caused by diferent genes on diferent chromosomes: 70% are autosomal dominant and 30% arise from sporadic mutations. NF-1 (Von Recklinghausen’s disease) is the commoner variant, afecting approximately 1:4000 births. It arises from a gene mutation on chromosome 17. Skin manifestations appear in early life, with the development of more than five smooth surfaced café-au-lait spots, subcutaneous neurofibromata, armpit or groin freckling and Lisch nodules. NF-2 produces multiple central nervous system tumours.

Determining operable tumors requires careful investigation. The TNM staging system provides prognostic information. Tumors graded up to T3, N1, M0 have improved prognosis when treated surgically. questions.text: Which is the most common pancreatic endocrine neoplasm?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Insulinoma Insulinomas are the most common pancreatic endocrine tumor. Insulinomas are the most common cause of hypoglycemia resulting from endogenous hyperinsulinism. Insulinomas are characterized clinically by the Whipple triad , as follows: Presence of symptoms of hypoglycemia low blood sugar at the time of symptoms Reversal of symptoms by glucose administration Failure of endogenous insulin secretion to be suppressed by hypoglycemia is the hallmark of an Insulinoma. The definitive management is surgical removal of the Insulinoma. This may involve removing part of the pancreas, as well ( Whipple procedure and distal pancreatectomy ).

Highyeild:

Insulinoma is the most common functioning tumor of the endocrine pancreas The average age at diagnosis is 45 years 97% of insulinomas are located in the pancreas (equally distributed in the head, body, and tail), while 3% are found in other areas such as the duodenum, splenic hilum, or gastrocolic ligament Insulinomas are typically small , with an average size of 0 to 1.5 cm The diagnostic hallmark of insulinoma is Whipple’s triad , which includes symptoms of hypoglycemia, low blood glucose levels (40-50 mg/dL), and relief of symptoms after the administration of glucose Clinical features of insulinoma include sympathetic overactivity in response to hypoglycemia, CNS disturbance, significant weight gain, and a painless condition The gold standard test for the diagnosis of insulinoma is the 72-hour fasting test An insulin-to-glucose ratio > 0.4 is consistent with insulinoma

Extraedge:

Localization techniques for insulinoma include angiography, portal venous sampling for insulin, and EUS with intra-operative palpation Treatment options for insulinoma include diazoxide, laparoscopic resection or enucleation, and distal pancreatectomy (depending on the location of the tumor) Streptozotocin, with or without 5-fluorouracil , is associated with improved survival in metastatic pancreatic endocrine tumors.

questions.text: Patient presented to emergency bay with stab injury to the lower chest & low pulses, the BP improved after giving IV fluids. Chest x-ray showed clear lung fields. Next step in the management?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

E-fast The extended-Focused Assessment with Sonography in Trauma (eFAST) should be done with the primary survey, especially in an unstable patient. eFAST allows for quick identification of chest areas with air and/or blood and helps focus definitive management. The 4 views of the traditional Focused Assessment with Sonography in Trauma (FAST) exam include the : Cardiac (subxiphoid) window, Right upper quadrant (RUQ, or Morrison’s pouch), Left upper quadrant (LUQ) Suprapubic (bladder) window. Presence of a black collection outside of an organ, viscera, or pericardia suggests a positive FAST exam. The eFAST includes pulmonary views and also evaluates for pneumothorax and hemothorax, in addition to the traditional 4 views. The primary survey identifies immediately life-threatening injuries. These injuries should be addressed at the time of identification. Potential injuries that should be ruled out include: Large hemothorax Large pneumothorax Pericardial effusion with or without tamponade Computed tomography (CT) is more sensitive and specific. However, this requires the patient to be stable for transport.

questions.text: Which of the following is correct in regard to the image given below?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Seen in chronic lymphoedema Edema in the dorsum of the foot is frequently described as a buffalo hump. Lymphedema is an accumulation of protein and fluid in the subcutaneous tissue that results from impaired transport of protein-rich lymphatic fluid from the interstitium. Inability to pick up the skin of the base of the toes is called a positive stemmer sign There are 4 stages of lymphedema: Stage 0 - subclinical lymphedema Stage 1 - early accumulation of fluid that is high in protein content, swelling may subside with limb elevation, and pitting of the skin may occur Stage 2 - pitting may not occur as tissue fibrosis develops, and limb elevation alone does not reduce swelling Stage 3 - a severe increase in limb swelling along with skin changes, including fibrosis, induration, warty overgrowths, and excess adipose tissue proliferation.

Highyeild:

Lymphoedema: Lymphoedema may be defined as abnormal limb swelling caused by the accumulation of increased amounts of high protein ISF secondary to defective lymphatic drainage in the presence of (near) normal net capillary filtration Pathology: Result of an inability of the existing lymphatic system to accommodate the protein and fluid entering the interstitial compartment at the tissue level. Stages : First Stage - Soft pitting edema (impaired lymphatic drainage results in protein-rich fluid accumulation in the interstitial compartment) Second Stage - Nonpitting and Spongy consistency (the clinical condition is further exacerbated by the accumulation of fibroblasts, adipocytes, and, perhaps most important, macrophages in the affected tissues, which culminates in a local inflammatory response) Third Stage - Lymphostatic Elephantiasis (excessive subcutaneous fibrosis and scarring with associated severe skin change). Edema is irreversible at this stage. Aetiological classification of lymphoedema: Primary lymphoedema Congenital (onset <2 years old): sporadic; familial (Nonne–Milroy’s disease) Praecox (onset 2–35 years old): sporadic; familial (Letessier–Meige’s disease) Tarda (onset after 35 years old) Secondary lymphoedema A parasitic infection (filariasis) Fungal infection (tinea pedis) Exposure to foreign body material (silica particles) Primary malignancy Metastatic spread to lymph nodes Radiotherapy to lymph nodes Surgical excision of lymph nodes Trauma (particularly degloving injuries) Superficial thrombophlebitis Deep venous thrombosis. Diagnosis : Unlike other types of edema, lymphoedema characteristically involves the foot. The contour of the ankle is lost through infilling of the Sub malleolar depressions, A ‘buffalo hump’ forms on the dorsum of the foot, The toes appear ‘square’ because of the confinement of footwear and The skin on the dorsum of the toes cannot be pinched because of subcutaneous fibrosis (Stemmer’s sign) . Lymphoedema usually spreads proximally to knee level & less commonly affects the whole leg. Chronic eczema, fungal infection of the skin (dermatophytosis) and nails (onychomycosis), fissuring, verrucae, and papillae (warts) are frequently seen in advanced diseases. Ulceration is unusual, except in the presence of chronic venous insufficiency Treatment: General Therapeutic Measures : Appropriate Antibiotics Maintenance of ideal body weight Elevation and Compression Garments: The ideal compression garment is custom fitted and delivers pressures in the range of 30 to 60 mm Hg. Limb Elevation at night Avoid standing for prolonged periods Complex Decongestive Physical Therapy Compression Pump Therapy (Pneumatic Compression therapy) Drug Therapy - Benzopyrones Molecular Lymphangiogenesis Operative Treatment: Reconstructive - should be considered for those patients with proximal (either primary or secondary) obstruction of the extremity lymphatic circulation with preserved, dilated lymphatics peripheral to the obstruction. Excisional - only viable option for patients without residual lymphatics of adequate size for reconstructive procedures. For patients with recalcitrant stage II and early stage III lymphedema in whom the edema is moderate and the skin is relatively healthy, an excisional procedure that removes a large segment of the lymphedematous subcutaneous tissues and the overlying skin is the procedure of choice

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B : Occurs due to parasitic infection not viral infection Option C : Not very common in children except congenital primary lymphoedema Option D : Involvement is not always bilateral

Extraedge:

Lymphedema is not curable, but the symptoms and long-term effects can be controlled with a combination of elastic compression stockings, limb elevation, pneumatic compression, and massage. Controlling the edema protects the skin and potentially prevents cellulitis

questions.text: A 5 year old child is diagnosed with acute liver failure. Which one of the following criteria are not included in the King's college criteria?

options.label: D
options.text: Jaundice less than 7 days before development of encephalopathy

questions.correct_answer: D. Jaundice less than 7 days before development of encephalopathy
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Jaundice less than 7 days before development of encephalopathy The King's College Criteria is used to determine if there is any early indices of poor prognosis in patients with acute liver failure. Acute liver failure is defined as the onset of encephalopathy or coagulopathy within 6 weeks of a patient diagnosed with liver disease. As liver transplantation becomes a more accessible option for patients with acute liver failure, the King's College Criteria serve a role in determining which patients may require transplantation. King’s College Criteria ALF due to acetaminophen toxicity: pH <7.3 or arterial serum lactate >3.0 mmol/L All three following conditions occur within a 24 hour period: Presence of grade 4 or 4 hepatic encephalopathy INR >6.5 Serum creatinine >3.4 mg/dL ALF due to other etiologies INR >6.5 and encephalopathy present (irrespective of grade) ANY three of the following conditions are present: Age <10 or >40 years Jaundice >7 days before development of encephalopathy INR > 5 Serum bilirubin > 17 mg/dL Unfavorabole etiology such as: Wilson disease Idiosyncratic drug reaction Seronegative hepatis

Highyeild:

King's College has established selection criteria for liver transplantation in cases of acute liver failure caused by paracetamol or non-paracetamol toxicity. For paracetamol toxicity , criteria are met if arterial pH <7.30 or INR >6.5, serum creatinine 3.4 mg/dL (301 µmol/L), and grade III/IV encephalopathy are present. For non-paracetamol toxicity , criteria are met if INR >6.5 or three out of five criteria are present: age, aetiology, duration of jaundice, PT, and serum bilirubin. Lactate or phosphate thresholds may improve sensitivity and negative predictive value. Hepatic encephalopathy grades range from 1 (inverted sleep pattern, agitation) to 4 (coma).

Extraedge:

The grading system for hepatic encephalopathy includes four grades. Grade 1 symptoms include inverted sleep pattern, agitation, forgetfulness, irritability, and apraxia. Grade 2 symptoms include lethargy, time/place disorientation, personality change, and ataxia. Grade 3 symptoms include somnolence to semistupor, place disorientation, asterixis, and hyperactive reflexes. Grade 4 includes the symptom of coma. Lactate or phosphate thresholds added to the criteria may improve sensitivity and negative predictive value.

#MANTRA King's College selection criteria for liver transplantation in acute liver failure CAUSE SELECTION CRITERIA Acetaminophen Arterial pH <7.30 irrespective of hepatic coma grade Or Prothrombin time >100 s + serum creatinine level >3.4 mg/dL + grade III or IV hepatic coma Not acetaminophen Prothrombin time >100 s irrespective of hepatic coma grade Or Any three of the following, irrespective of hepatic coma grade: Cryptogenic or drug-induced hepatitis Serum bilirubin level >17.5 mg/dL Jaundice to coma interval >7 d Prothrombin time >50 s Age <10 y or >40 y

questions.text: What is the child Pugh class for patient who has a serum bilirubin of 2.5 mg/dl, S albumin – 3 g/dl, INR of 2. Mild Ascites is present but there is no encephalopathy.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

CP B The Child-Pugh score is a system for assessing the prognosis — including the required strength of treatment and necessity of liver transplant — of chronic liver disease, primarily cirrhosis. Child- Turcotte- Pugh Classification for Severity of Cirrhosis 1 2 3 Encephalopathy None Grade 1-2 (or precipitant induced) Grade 3-4 (or chronic) Ascites None Mild to moderate (diuretic responsive) Severe (diuretic refractory) Bilirubin (mg/dL) < 2 2-3 >3 Albumin (g/dL) >3.5 2.8-3.5 <2.8 INR <1.7 1.7-2.3 >2.3 Child- Turcotte- Pugh Class obtained by adding score for each parameter (total points) Class A = 5 to 6 points (least severe liver disease) Class B = 7 to 9 points (moderately severe liver disease) Class C = 10 to 15 points (most severe liver disease)

Highyeild:

Child-Turcotte-Pugh (CTP) classification The Child-Turcotte-Pugh (CTP) Scoring System is a tool used to assess hepatic function in liver diseases. Initially , it was created to classify patients into risk groups before undergoing porto-systemic shunt surgeries. The CTP score is now used to assess prognosis in cirrhosis and other liver diseases , with Class A having 5-6 points Class B having 7-9 points Class C having 10-15 points. Major surgeries can only be performed in Class A, minor surgica l procedures can be done in Class B, and no surgical intervention should be done in Class C. For patients in Class C, the best treatment option is liver transplantation.
